doc.title: China Resources Land (1109.HK)
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/China Resources Land 1109.HK 1H25 above expectation on margins more room for profitability recovery reiterate Buy on CLC_2025-08-28

passages.text: CRLs 1H25 core profit declined \(7\%\) yo to Rmb10bn (below our flattish 2025E earnings outlook), mainly dragged by provisions (Rmb1.2bn impact on bottomline). Overall, we view the results as solid: 1) above- expected topline bookings \((+20\%)\) yo in 1H25, vs. \(+3\%\) prior FY25E); 2) steady DP booking margin (c. \(16\%\) in 1H25) which aligns with our view that margins are bottoming- out and exceeded management's earlier guidance of c. \(14\% - 15\%\) for 2025- 26; 3) upbeat shopping mall performance (rental income growth inline at \(+10\%\) yo) underpinned by retail sales outperformance \((+9\%\) SSSG vs. nationwide social retail sales was \(+5\%\) in 1H25), while profitability surpassed expectation ( \(78\%\) GPM, 2pp ahead of prior FY25E). Looking ahead, we remain optimistic on CRLs margin recovery given its well- maintained land bank exposure to Tier- 1/2 cities \((- 70\%\) by end- 1H), improved NT saleable structure ( \(90\%\) located in Tier 1/2 and c. \(45\%\) newly launched), already evident YTD cash margin improvement for newly acquired projects, safeguarded by an accelerated yet disciplined land banking strategy that continues to prioritize profitability.

Post results, we raise our 2025E- 27E topline estimates by average \(4\%\) , and keep our 2025E- 27E EPS estimates largely unchanged after fine- tuning the profitability profile. Accordingly, after factoring in the latest land acquisitions, we raise our 2025E NAV to HK \(42.2 per share from HK\) 40.6 and our 12- month NAV- based target price to HK \(38.0 (from HK\) 36.5 previously, still at a \(10\%\) NAV discount). CRL is trading at a \(28\%\) discount to its end- 25E NAV, 0.9X 2025E P/B and implying \(25\%\) upside, vs. coverage average of \(27\%\) , 0.5X, and \(10\%\) . Reiterate Buy (on CL).

1. Contract sales outlook: CRL recorded 7M25 property sales of Rmb124bn, down \(12\%\) yo (vs. average \(18\% / - 8\%\) yo amongst coverage/SOE peers) and accounted for \(44\%\) of our prior full-year target (vs. \(54\%\) in 7M24). Factoring in lower YTD sell-through, we moderately cut our CRL contract sales by \(3\%\) to Rmb274bn in 2025E, or \(+5\%\) yo. The revised target also implies a \(42\%\) sell-through rate, higher than \(37\%\) in 2H24, given enhanced saleable structure for the rest of the year (88% located in tier 1/2 cities and \(43\%\) will be new projects to be launched, improving
from \(85\% /25\%\) for 2H24 respectively).

2. Land banking re-accelerated with disciplined strategy: CRL acquired 18 projects in 1H25 with Rmb44.7bn/Rmb32.3bn in total/attri land premium, representing \(\sim 75\%\) yoy improvement under both metrics. Land spending also accounted for \(41\%\) of total contracted sales in 1H25, accelerating from \(21\% /38\%\) in 1H/2H24 but still below the FY21-FY23 average intensity of \(50\%\) . Looking into 2H25, management reaffirmed its investment strategy to set investment budgets based on sales performance and dynamic cash flow projections, with focus on ensuring quick turnover of saleable resources, and to remain committed to opportunities in central areas of T-1/2 cities with profitability as priority. This is echoed by our tracking which indicates cash GPM of CRL's YTD acquired projects has likely improved to the high-twenties range, compared to \(c.20\%\) in 2024. Factoring in the YTD land banking, CRL's end-1H25 land bank stood at 49mn sqm (-6% from end-24), with tier-1/2 cities exposure maintained at \(70\%\) (largely unchanged from end-24).

3. Balance sheet steady under 3RL metrics: 1) total liability to total asset ratio (excl. presales deposit) down to \(56\%\) , -1pp vs. end-24; 2) net gearing ratio up to \(40\%\) , +7pp vs. end-24, driven by Rmb20bn of net addition of interest-bearing debt in 1H25; 3) cash to short-term debt ratio improved to 1.93X, +0.1X vs. end-24. Blended borrowing cost was further lowered to \(2.79\%\) in 1H25 from \(3.11\%\) for 2024, with average debt tenor at 6.4 years by end-1H (vs. 6.7 years by end-24).
1. 1H25 revenue rose \(20\%\) yoy to Rmb95bn, accounting for \(32\% /35\%\) of prior FY25 GSe and consensus (vs. \(28\%\) in 1H24. By segment:

Development property: 1H25 booking revenue rose \(26\%\) yoy to Rmb74bn, mainly driven by stronger booking ASP (+36% yoy) which offset the delivery volume decline (-7% yoy). We note the stronger ASP recognized was mainly reflecting higher representation of high-tier cities within revenue mix (T-1 cities accounted for \(46\%\) of 1H25 revenue booking vs. \(11\% /31\%\) in 1H/2H24). By end-1H25, the company had unbooked sales of Rmb306bn (+4% from Rmb294bn by end-24), amongst which - Rmb160bn can be booked in 2H25 (accounting for \(89\%\) of our updated 2H25E DP revenue forecast, vs. unbooked sales by end-1H23/24 which accounted for \(90\% /93\%\) of 2H23/24 DP revenue).
Investment property business: IP rental income (incl. malls, offices and hotels) rose by \(6\%\) yoy to Rmb12.1bn. By segment:

Shopping mall rental income rose by \(10\%\) yoy (inline with FY25 GSe), supported by (i) retail sales improving \(20\% /9\%\) yoy on aggregate/same-store basis; (ii) launch of 2 malls totaling GFA0.4mn sqm in 1H25, representing \(c.3\%\) incremental commercial GFA added to portfolio; (iii) occupancy rate improved to \(97.3\%\) (+0.2pp vs. end-24 level). Occupancy cost ratio remained at reasonable level, edging down 0.2pp/0.5pp from FY24/1H24 level to \(12.0\%\) .
Office rental income fell \(14\%\) yoy (vs. \(+3\%\) yoy in prior FY25E) to Rmb0.81bn, implying lower rental rate as occupancy stayed flattish at \(75\%\)

Hotel rental income fell \(16\%\) yoy (vs. flatish yoy in prior FY25E) to Rmb0.87bn, deregistered project disposals. Operating performance remained stable with average room rate falling \(2\%\) yoy while occupancy improved to \(64\%\) vs. \(62\%\) in 1H20.
2. Gross margin: 1H25 GPM rose by 2pp hoh and 3pp yoy, 3pp above both prior GSe and consensus. By segment:

1H25 DP GPM recorded - 3pp hoh/+3pp yoy to \(16\%\) (inline with prior FY25E GSe, and ahead of c. \(13\% - 14\%\) 2025- 26 GPM per prior management guidance). Excluding inventory provision (Rmb1.55bn consolidated in 1H25 vs. Rmb4.5bn/3bn in 2H/1H24), GPM would have recorded - 3pp hoh/+1pp yoy to \(18\%\) vs. \(21\% /17\%\) in 2H/1H24. 1H25 shopping mall and office GPM improved 5pp hoh and 1pp yoy to \(78\%\) , 2pp ahead of our prior FY25E GSe, but hotel GPM weakened 2pp hoh and 2pp yoy to \(10\%\) , trailing 2pp behind prior FY25E GSe.

3. Net margin: 1H25 core margin rose by 3pp hoh but declined 3pp yoy, 2pp above prior GSe and consensus. The sequential improvement was mainly driven by higher representation of recurring income channels (incl. IP/PM/eco-system business, \(53\%\) of 1H25 core profit vs. \(49\%\) in 1H24).

4. The company declared an interim dividend per share of Rmb0.20 (flatish yoy), implying a \(12\%\) payout against core profit (vs. \(14\%\) in 1H24), which implies \(0.7\%\) interim dividend yield on Aug 27th closing.
Key risks: Revenue booking and rental profitability below our expectations; slower-than- expected scale expansion; mall opening delay due to supply pressure and macro hard landing.
Exhibit 1:CRL 1H25 earnings comparison

China Resources Land (CRL), a state- owned enterprise, ranked 3rd on the 2024 Chinese property developers list (in terms of sales, ranked by CRIC). We are Buy rated on CRL 1) due to its strong balance sheet and brand in the property development business, as well as leading expertise and track- record in managing the shopping mall business; 2) as we believe CRL is well positioned in this industry downturn to strengthen its leadership in both property development and the shopping mall business; and 3) as we expect CRL to

maintain its top- 5 ranking in terms of scale in the coming years, for which we think the current valuation hasn't priced in. We believe CRL remains undervalued vs. other quality DP names and its historical trading range. Key catalyst: continuous local policy easing to stimulate demand and better resolution for distressed POEs, which will help to restore market confidence and sales recovery, in our view.

We, Yi Wang, CFA, Shi Xu and Kaiyan Jing, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect our personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character- risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fom_disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.

You are permitted to store, display, analyze, modify, reformat, and print the information made available to you via this service only for your own use. You may not resell or reverse engineer this information to calculate or develop any index for disclosure and/or marketing or create any other derivative works or commercial product(s), data or offering(s) without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. You are not permitted to publish, transmit, or otherwise reproduce this information, in whole or in part, in any format to any third party without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. This foregoing restriction includes, without limitation, using, extracting, downloading or retrieving this information, in whole or in part, to train or finetune a machine learning or artificial intelligence system, or to provide or reproduce this information, in whole or in part, as a prompt or input to any such system.
